In both West and East Harlem, third-party air quality monitors report minimum fine particulate matter (PM2.5) values higher than New York City reported pollution values.

Publicly-available real-time PM2.5 data was collected from April 14 to April 16, 2023 across three indoor PurpleAir sensors in Manhattanville, Hamilton Heights, and East Harlem.

Note: Colors show relative rate of asthma-related ER visits for 2017-2019.

Maximum, average, and minimum air pollution measurements

Hamilton Heights

125

Manhattanville

East Harlem (South)

100

For West and East Harlem, NYC reported in 2021 an average annual PM2.5 level of 6.8 micrograms/cubic meter.

60%

75

81%

53

50

50

46

25

76%

Manhattanville

East Harlem

Hamilton Heights

sensor location

At an East Harlem sensor, 76% of measurements exceeded the EPA Air Quality Index PM2.5 24-hour standard of 35 micrograms per cubic meter.

Source: PurpleAir Real-Time Air Quality Map. Sensor IDs: 140004, 82929, 89957.

Note: 2023 data was found to be comparable to 2021 PurpleAir data collected in West Harlem.

Graphic by Adina Cazacu-De Luca
